author: Jay Yeomans
title: Sunday Morning QB: Stars and stats from BYU's blowout win over Wagner
text:
A look at how the Cougars performed in their big win over Wagner on Saturday afternoon.
Upcoming Games BYU Football BYU football stats & schedule BYU @ SJ State Spartan Stadium, San Jose Nov. 6, 9:30 p.m. 12 Days 12 Hrs 1 Min 48 Secs More Coverage BYU report card: Cougars roll over Wagner BYU football video: Top 5 backup quarterback plays against Wagner BYU QB Hoge, other backups, receive valuable experience in win over Wagner BYU makes the most of scheduled win over outmanned Wagner in 70-6 blowout Playing BYU a bittersweet experience for Wagner players and coaches In a game that saw plenty of Cougars get their first action of the season, BYU came away with a 70-6 win over the Wagner Seahawks at LaVell Edwards Stadium on Saturday afternoon.
The Cougars got the offense going right away with four first-quarter touchdowns and never looked back as they improved to 6-2 on the season.
Scoring recap
BYU scored its first of seven first-half touchdowns when Tanner Mangum connected with Colby Pearson for a 16-yard touchdown. One of the plays that set up the score was a 34-yard completion from Mangum to Mitchell Juergens.
The Cougars opened up a two-score lead when Mangum found Mitch Mathews for a 20-yard touchdown. Francis Bernard carried the load on the three-play drive with runs of 7 and 21 yards.
After another Wagner punt, the Cougars were back in the end zone when Algernon Brown broke free for a 42-yard touchdown run. Another nice play on the possession came when Mangum found Nick Kurtz for a 14-yard gain.
Brown found the pay dirt from 37 yards out as the Cougars took a 28-0 first-quarter lead. A key play on the drive came when Bernard picked up 7 yards on third-and-3 to keep the drive alive.
Mathews scored his second touchdown of the half when he and Mangum hooked up for a 19-yard touchdown. The score was set up by a leaping 46-yard catch from Terenn Houk on third-and-8 that gave the Cougars the ball deep in the Seahawks' territory.
Bernard got into the act when he scored from 1-yard out to push the lead to 42-0. The touchdown was set up by first-down receptions from Devon Blackmon and Juergens as well as a first-down run from Bernard.
Beau Hoge scored his first touchdown as a Cougar from 2 yards out to give the Cougars a 49-point advantage. BYU moved the ball all 40 yards of the drive on the ground, including a 16-yard run from Hoge.
Wagner got on the board on the first possession of the second half when Matthias McKinnon scored from 1-yard out on third-and-goal. Alex Thomson came up big for the Seahawks with three third-down conversions through the air and one on the ground.
The Cougars answered when Hoge found David Kessler for a 47-yard touchdown. Josh Weeks made a big play to keep the chains when he gained 13 yards on a pass from Hoge on third-and-7.
Nate Carter gave BYU its ninth touchdown of the day when he found a huge hole and exploded for a 70-yard rushing score.
Hoge scored the last touchdown of the day on a 1-yard run that capped off the longest BYU possession of the day. Akile Davis came up with a key play when he extended the drive, thanks to a 9-yard reception on third-and-2.
Three stars
3. Beau Hoge
Hoge had his best showing as a Cougar. He completed 8 of 11 passes for 117 yards and a touchdown to go along with 12 rushes for 47 yards and two more scores.
2. Algernon Brown
Brown had two big first-quarter touchdown runs to open up the early lead. He totaled just six carries for 109 yards and the two scores.
1. Tanner Mangum
Mangum had a stellar first-half before he was replaced by Hoge. He completed 12 of 13 passes for 237 yards, including touchdowns of 16, 20 and 19 yards.
Analyzing the stats
While the Seahawks won the time of possession battle, BYU outgained Wagner 741-129. The Cougars also had a 31-6 advantage in first downs.
Of BYU's 10 touchdown drive, six took less than two minutes. The lone Wagner scoring possession was 8:08.
The BYU signal callers finished the game having completed 23 of 27 passes for 411 yards and four touchdowns, including a perfect 3 of 3 by Koy Detmer Jr. for 57 yards. Wagner threw for 46 yards on the day.
Even though 31 passes were completed in the game, neither team had a player catch more than three passes (Mathews, David Kessler and Josh Weeks had three receptions each).
Of the 129 yards the Cougar defense gave up, 70 came on the opening drive of the second half. Wagner gained more than 10 yards on a possession only one other time in the game.
Up next
The Cougars have the week off to prepare for a matchup with the San Jose State Spartans. The Spartans are 4-4 on the season, including 3-2 in the Mountain West. They have wins over New Hampshire, Fresno State, UNLV and New Mexico. Their four losses have come at the hands of Air Force, Oregon State, Auburn and San Diego State.
The one player that the Cougars must account for if they expect to come away with the road win is running back Tyler Ervin. He has been dominant on the ground much of the season with 193 carries for 1,159 yards and 12 touchdowns. He has also done some nice things in the passing game with 30 catches for 232 yards and two scores.
